snippet: A surfboard from the forgettable 1964 movie ''Ride the Wild Surf'' rests in a corner of one gallery at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Another gallery displays plaintive visions of Mexicans in California by 1930's muralists like Diego Rivera...
lead_paragraph: A surfboard from the forgettable 1964 movie ''Ride the Wild Surf'' rests in a corner of one gallery at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Another gallery displays plaintive visions of Mexicans in California by 1930's muralists like Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and David Alfaro Siqueiros. A third shows harrowing photographs documenting the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II. Nearby are lavish impressionist-style paintings from the early 20th century of the breaking fog in Santa Barbara and the moonrise over San Diego Bay. Stark and emotional photographs by Dorothea Lange of Depression-era migrant mothers and factory workers are steps from a gallery displaying a 1998 Playboy magazine with ''The Babes of Baywatch'' on the cover.
abstract: Culture of California is subject of enormous landmark exhibition at Los Angeles County Museum of Art; show, called Made in California: Art, Image and Identity 1900-2000, offers revisionist view of state and its cultural legacy, from serious to silly, from dynamic and adventurous to bigoted and violent; photos (M)

headline.main: Beyond Tans and Tinsel; A New Los Angeles Museum Show Seeks to Smash California Cliches
